questions.text: A 57-year-old multiparous woman comes to the physician because of urinary leakage for the past 6 months. She involuntarily loses a small amount of urine after experiencing a sudden, painful sensation in the bladder. She has difficulty making it to the bathroom in time and feels nervous when there is no bathroom nearby. She also started having to urinate at night. She does not have hematuria, abdominal pain, or pelvic pain. She has insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus and underwent surgical treatment for symptomatic pelvic organ prolapse 3 years ago. Menopause was 6 years ago, and she is not on hormone replacement therapy. She works as an administrative manager and drinks 3–4 cups of coffee daily at work. On physical examination, there is no suprapubic tenderness. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities and Q-tip test is negative. Ultrasound of the bladder shows a normal postvoid residual urine volume. Which of the following is the primary underlying cause of this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Urge incontinence can result from detrusor muscle overactivity, which causes involuntary contraction of the detrusor muscle and urinary tenesmus that lead to a sudden release of urine. Anticholinergic agents (e.g., oxybutynin) can help treat this condition by decreasing detrusor muscle tone.

See “Overview of urinary incontinence” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Overflow incontinence (due to impaired detrusor muscle contractility or bladder outlet obstruction) results in increased urine bladder volumes. Patients with overflow incontinence usually have continuous urinary leakage or dribbling (not sudden episodes of urinary loss), and postvoid residual urine volumes would be increased.

C) INCORRECT:

Trauma to the urinary tract (e.g., due to childbirth) can cause pelvic floor muscle weakening and urethral hypermobility so that the urethra and bladder neck cannot completely close against the anterior vaginal wall. As a result, increases in intraabdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, lifting), force urine through an incompletely closed urethra (stress incontinence). However, this patient has no evidence of stress incontinence (her Q-tip test is negative, has leakage of urine unrelated to coughing).

D) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infection can cause or worsen urinary incontinence (due to urethral irritation). Although infection should be ruled out in this patient, it is unlikely that this is the etiology of her incontinence, as she lacks any other signs of urinary tract infection (e.g., suprapubic tenderness, dysuria, hematuria).

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased estrogen levels in postmenopausal women can result in atrophy of the urethral mucosal layers (e.g., decreased urethral mucosal seal, decreased urethral compliance, increased urethral irritation), all of which can contribute to incontinence. Although this patient's postmenopausal estrogen levels may be a contributing factor for her incontinence, her sudden urge to void with loss of urine suggests that urge incontinence is the primary etiology.

F) INCORRECT:

Excessive caffeine consumption can exacerbate the symptoms of urinary incontinence by increasing the volume of daily urine and irritating the bladder lining. Therefore, this patient should be advised to limit her caffeine consumption. However, caffeine consumption itself does not cause urinary incontinence.

G) INCORRECT:

Early-stage pelvic organ prolapse (POP) and stress incontinence often co-occur, as both can result from vaginal wall weakening. Since the patient underwent surgery for POP in the past, a recurrent POP is possible, but prolapse does not cause urinary incontinence itself. In fact, advanced stages of POP may be associated with improvements in incontinence due to kinking of the urethra. Importantly, POP is not associated with urge incontinence.

H) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence can result from decreased pelvic floor muscle tone in which the urethra and bladder neck cannot completely close against the anterior vaginal wall. As a result, increases in intraabdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, lifting) force urine through an incompletely closed urethra. Although this patient was likely suffering from decreased pelvic floor muscle tone before she underwent surgical treatment for symptomatic pelvic organ prolapse, she currently has no evidence of stress incontinence (her Q-tip test is negative, she has leakage of urine unrelated to coughing).
questions.hint: This patient most likely has urge incontinence, as evidenced by her sudden urge to urinate resulting in frequent small volume voids. This condition can also cause nocturia, and be exacerbated by bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine).

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary incontinence. The urge to urinate occurs suddenly, and he often is unable to make it to the bathroom before leaking urine. He has no incontinence with coughing or laughing. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a normal post-void residual volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxazosin, an alpha-1 antagonist that causes relaxation of the bladder sphincter muscle, is used in the treatment of urinary retention and concomitant overflow incontinence due to an overactive sphincter or BPH. A normal post-void residual volume makes urinary retention unlikely in this patient. This patient with urge incontinence has an overactive bladder with heightened detrusor tone; relaxation of the urinary sphincter could worsen his symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Bethanechol, a parasympathomimetic agent, is used in the treatment of urinary retention and concomitant overflow incontinence due to an underactive detrusor, which can occasionally occur in patients with multiple sclerosis due to lesions below S1 spinal level. A normal post-void residual volume makes urinary retention unlikely in this patient. This patient with urge incontinence has an overactive bladder with heightened detrusor tone; increasing it further would likely worsen his symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Midodrine, an alpha-1 agonist that causes contraction of the urinary sphincter and detrusor, is used in the treatment of underactive bladder sphincter (stress incontinence), which can occur in patients with multiple sclerosis due to demyelinating lesions below S1 spinal level. However, stress incontinence presents with dribbling of urine during laughing or coughing, which is not reported in this patient. This patient with urge incontinence already has a heightened detrusor tone; increasing it further would likely worsen his symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that affects the central nervous system (CNS) and is used in the treatment of dementia. Rivastigmine is not used to treat urinary incontinence.

E) INCORRECT:

Mirtazapine, an alpha-2 antagonist, is used to treat depression, which often occurs in patients with multiple sclerosis. However, mirtazapine is not used to treat urinary incontinence because alpha-2 adrenergic receptors do not play a role in maintaining urinary continence. An alpha-1 antagonist can be used to treat certain forms of urinary incontinence.

F) CORRECT:

In a healthy individual, bladder wall relaxation due to stimulation of β3 receptors in the detrusor muscle allows storage of urine. During the storage phase, contraction of the trigone and sphincter muscles due to stimulation of α1 receptors at these sites maintains continence. Bladder wall contraction due to stimulation of M3 receptors in the detrusor muscle, and reflex inhibition of the trigone and sphincter allows for micturition to occur during the voiding phase. Muscarinic antagonists (e.g. tolterodine, oxybutynin, solifenacin, dicyclomine) and the newly developed β3 agonists (e.g., mirabegron) relax detrusor muscles, and can therefore be used to treat urge incontinence caused by an overactive detrusor muscle.
questions.hint: In a patient with multiple sclerosis, a sudden urge to urinate that is not related to increased intra-abdominal pressure is consistent with urge incontinence due to detrusor hyperreflexia (upper motor neuron dysfunction!).

questions.text: A 60-year-old multiparous woman comes to the physician because of urinary leakage for the past 4 months. She involuntarily loses a small amount of urine after experiencing a sudden, painful sensation in the bladder. She wakes up at night several times to urinate, and she sometimes cannot make it to the bathroom in time. She has diabetes mellitus type 2 controlled with insulin and a history of pelvic organ prolapse, for which she underwent surgical treatment 5 years ago. Menopause was 11 years ago. She drinks 4-5 cups of coffee daily. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities, and a Q-tip test is negative. Ultrasound of the bladder shows a normal postvoid residual urine. Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Early stage pelvic organ prolapse and stress incontinence often co-occur, as both can result from vaginal wall weakening. Since the patient underwent surgery for pelvic organ prolapse in the past, a recurrent pelvic organ prolapse is possible, but prolapse does not cause urinary incontinence in itself. In fact, advanced stages of pelvic organ prolapse may be associated with improvements in incontinence due to kinking of the urethra. Importantly, pelvic organ prolapse is not associated with urge incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence can result from decreased pelvic floor muscle tone in which the urethra and bladder neck cannot completely close against the anterior vaginal wall. As a result, increases in intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, lifting) force urine through an incompletely closed urethra. Although this patient was likely suffering from decreased pelvic floor muscle tone before she underwent surgical treatment for symptomatic pelvic organ prolapse, she currently has no evidence of stress incontinence (her Q-tip test is negative, has leakage of urine unrelated to coughing).

C) CORRECT:

Urge incontinence can result from increased detrusor muscle activity, which causes involuntary detrusor muscle contraction and urinary tenesmus that lead to a sudden release of urine. Antimuscarinic agents (e.g., oxybutynin) can help treat this condition by decreasing detrusor muscle tone.

D) INCORRECT:

Autonomic diabetic neuropathy can lead to an underactive detrusor that does not effectively contract enough to empty, resulting in overflow incontinence. Despite this patient's history of diabetes mellitus, overflow incontinence usually causes continuous urinary leakage or dribbling (not sudden episodes of urinary loss), and postvoid residual urine volumes would be increased.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive caffeine consumption can exacerbate the symptoms of urinary incontinence by increasing the volume of daily urine (due to the caffeine's diuretic effect) and irritating the bladder lining. Therefore, this patient should be advised to limit her caffeine consumption. However, caffeine consumption in itself does not cause urinary incontinence.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased estrogen levels in postmenopausal women can result in atrophy of the urethral mucosal layers (e.g., decreased urethral mucosal seal, decreased urethral compliance, increased urethral irritation), all of which can contribute to incontinence. Although this patient's postmenopausal estrogen levels may be a contributing factor for her incontinence, her sudden urge to void with loss of urine suggests that urge incontinence is the primary etiology.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has urge incontinence, as evidenced by her sudden urge to urinate resulting in frequent small volume voids. This condition can also cause nocturia, and be exacerbated by bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine).

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, she was diagnosed with overactive bladder syndrome and began treatment with oxybutynin. She continues to have involuntary loss of urine with sudden episodes of significant bladder discomfort that is only relieved by voiding. A substance is injected into the detrusor muscle to treat her symptoms. The physician informs the patient that she will have transitory relief for several months before symptoms return and will require repeated treatment. The injected substance is most likely produced by an organism with which of the following microbiological properties?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis is a gram-negative, encapsulated diplococcus. Although N. meningitidis does not secrete exotoxins, the lipooligosaccharides on its outer membrane act as endotoxins. However, endotoxins have no role in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis is a gram-negative, aerobic coccobacillus. B. pertussis produces pertussis toxin, which plays a central role in the pathogenesis of whooping cough. However, it has no role in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a gram-positive, club-shaped rod. C. diphtheriae produces diphtheria toxin, which can cause pharyngitis with pseudomembranes and severe lymphadenopathy. However, diphtheria toxin has no role in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Vibrio cholerae is a gram-negative, comma-shaped rod that produces cholera toxin. This toxin causes voluminous “rice-water” diarrhea by permanently activating Gs alpha subunit, thus overactivating adenylate cyclase and increasing the level of cAMP, which subsequently increases Cl− secretion and H2O efflux in the gastrointestinal lumen. Cholera toxin is not used in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Botulinum toxin is produced by Clostridium botulinum, which is a gram-positive, spore-forming rod. Botulinum toxin is a protease that cleaves SNARE, thereby impairing the fusion of acetylcholine-containing vesicles with the presynaptic membrane of the motor end plates. This irreversibly inhibits acetylcholine release, resulting in muscle paralysis. Endoscopic injection of botulinum toxin at different points in the bladder wall suppresses involuntary bladder contractions and thus improves the symptoms of overactive bladder syndrome.
Image Description:

Left image: physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end plate
– Action potential reaches the motor end plate → SNARE protein complex facilitates the fusion of vesicles containing acetylcholine (ACh) with the prejunctional membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh with ACh receptors on the postjunctional membrane → opening of the ion channels of ACh receptors → depolarization of the muscle
– Acetylcholinesterase present on the postjunctional membrane breaks down ACh and releases it into the neuromuscular junction cleft → choline is taken up by the choline transporter on the prejunctional membrane and recycled in ACh synthesis

Right image: cleavage of SNARE proteins by botulinum toxin
– Botulinum toxin is endocytosed by cholinergic axon terminals (depicted in the left image)
– The light chain of botulinum toxin released into the prejunctional neuron cleaves the SNARE protein complex → failure of fusion of vesicles containing ACh with the presynaptic membrane → ACh is not released into the neuromuscular junction → neural impulse is not transmitted to the muscle → flaccid paralysis of the muscle

F) INCORRECT:

Both Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes are gram-positive, β-hemolytic cocci. S. aureus produces several toxins, such as toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 and exfoliative toxin A. S. pyogenes produces streptolysin O and erythrogenic exotoxin A. However, none of these toxins are used in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.
questions.hint: The physician most likely injected botulinum toxin into this patient's detrusor muscle to provide relief for her refractory overactive bladder syndrome.

questions.text:
A physically active 65-year-old woman presents for evaluation of urinary incontinence. She reports that several times per week, she has a sudden urge to urinate and does not reach the toilet quickly enough. She also complains of nocturia and urinary frequency during the day. She has delivered three children vaginally, each more than 30 years ago. She had a myocardial infarction 2 years ago. Her current medications are aspirin and atenolol.
Vital signs and pelvic examination are normal. On urinalysis, the dipstick is negative for leukocyte esterase and nitrates, the urine pH is 5.0 (reference range, 5.0–9.0), and specific gravity is 1.010 (1.001–1.035). Microscopy reveals 2 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) and 2 squamous cells per high-power field.
The patient attempts bladder training with timed voiding, pelvic-floor therapy (commonly known as Kegel exercises), and avoidance of bladder irritants for 6 months but has no improvement.
Which one of the following management steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A vaginal pessary is used for stress incontinence, not urge incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic studies and an evaluation of the postvoid residual are not typically indicated in the evaluation of patients with urge incontinence unless more complicated forms of incontinence, such as overflow incontinence, are suspected. This patient’s symptoms are consistent with urge incontinence and therefore do not require evaluation with urodynamic studies unless pharmacologic treatment fails.

C) INCORRECT:

A urine culture is not indicated in a patient who has a normal urinalysis without pyuria.

D) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing atenolol (a beta-blocker) would be appropriate if the patient’s symptoms were temporally tied to initiation of that medication. Many medications, including both beta-blockers and calcium-channel blockers (e.g., amlodipine), can contribute to the development of incontinence.

E) CORRECT:

Urinary incontinence, which is common in women aged ≥65, usually manifests as urge or stress incontinence. Urge incontinence is defined as the involuntary leakage of urine, associated with a sudden, compelling desire to void. Leakage of urine before reaching the toilet, a typical symptom of urge incontinence, occurs when the bladder contracts with little warning and overcomes the sphincter mechanism. Other signs associated with overactive bladder and urge incontinence include nocturia and daytime frequency. Individuals with stress incontinence leak urine when there is a sudden increase in abdominal pressure and malfunction of the urethral sphincter.

Initial management for urge incontinence typically involves bladder training (patient education and “timed voiding”), pelvic muscle exercises, modification of fluid intake, and avoidance of irritants. However, anticholinergic antimuscarinic agents are the mainstay of therapy and are more effective than bladder training alone. Tolterodine is a reasonable first-line choice that can be given in a once-daily formulation.

Key learning point: The most appropriate pharmacologic therapy for a postmenopausal woman with urge incontinence is an anticholinergic agent.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old woman presents for evaluation of urinary symptoms. She has a 6- to 8-month history of a strong urge to urinate and occasional leakage of urine before she can get to the bathroom. Her neurologic examination is unremarkable. Pelvic examination shows no evidence of mass or prolapse. Her BMI is 36. A urinalysis is normal.
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Ask the patient to complete a voiding diary
Schedule transvaginal ultrasonography of the pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic studies are invasive tests that simulate the filling and emptying phases of micturition to assess for detrusor overactivity, bladder outlet obstruction, and detrusor sphincter dyssynergia. Given the invasive nature of this testing, it is not considered an appropriate study for initial evaluation of patients who present with urge urinary incontinence and overactive bladder symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring the post-void residual urine is not indicated in this patient, given the absence of obstructive urinary symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

A common symptom of overactive bladder is urge urinary incontinence (UUI), as described in this case. Evaluating a patient with suspected UUI requires taking a complete history, conducting neurologic and pelvic examinations as part of the physical examination, and ordering a urinalysis. The next step is to then evaluate both subjective (patient-reported) and objective (bladder or voiding diary) outcomes, to assess the severity of the symptoms.

A voiding diary can help to quantify the patient's voiding and incontinence episodes, which can be useful for both the clinician and the patient. During the initial evaluation phase, the diary provides information that can help the clinician plan appropriate components of intervention, particularly behavioral intervention. Recording the times that the patient voids provides a foundation for determining voiding intervals in bladder training programs. The diary can also be used during the course of treatment to track the effectiveness of various treatment components and guide the intervention. Completing the diary can also help enhance patients' awareness of their voiding habits and help them recognize activities that trigger their incontinence.

Key learning point: The first step in evaluating a woman with urge urinary incontinence, no obstructive symptoms, and a normal physical examination and urinalysis is to ask her to complete a voiding diary.

D) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic therapy is not appropriate until precipitating factors are identified and remediated when possible.

E) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the pelvis is not warranted in this patient, given her normal findings on physical examination.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the office because of urinary leakage for the past 6 months. She involuntarily loses a small amount of urine after experiencing a sudden, painful sensation in the bladder. She has difficulty making it to the bathroom in time and has started having to urinate at night. She does not have hematuria, abdominal pain, or pelvic pain. Menopause was 6 years ago. She drinks 3–4 cups of coffee daily at work. On physical examination, there are no abnormalities and Q-tip test is negative. Ultrasound of the bladder shows a normal postvoid residual urine volume. Which of the following is the primary underlying cause of this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Urge incontinence can result from detrusor muscle overactivity, which causes involuntary contraction of the detrusor muscle and urinary tenesmus that lead to a sudden release of urine. Anticholinergic agents (e.g., oxybutynin) can help treat this condition by decreasing detrusor muscle tone.

See “Overview of urinary incontinence” table.

Key learning point: Urge incontinence is primarily caused by increased detrusor muscle activity, leading to involuntary bladder contractions and sudden urinary urgency.

B) INCORRECT:

Overflow incontinence (due to impaired detrusor muscle contractility or bladder outlet obstruction) results in increased urine bladder volumes. Patients with overflow incontinence usually have continuous urinary leakage or dribbling (not sudden episodes of urinary loss), and postvoid residual urine volumes would be increased.

C) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infection can cause or worsen urinary incontinence (due to urethral irritation). Although infection should be ruled out in this patient, it is unlikely that this is the etiology of her incontinence, as she lacks any other signs of urinary tract infection (e.g., suprapubic tenderness, dysuria, hematuria).

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased estrogen levels in postmenopausal women can result in atrophy of the urethral mucosal layers (e.g., decreased urethral mucosal seal, decreased urethral compliance, increased urethral irritation), all of which can contribute to incontinence. Although this patient's postmenopausal estrogen levels may be a contributing factor for her incontinence, her sudden urge to void with loss of urine suggests that urge incontinence is the primary etiology.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive caffeine consumption can exacerbate the symptoms of urinary incontinence by increasing the volume of daily urine and irritating the bladder lining. Therefore, this patient should be advised to limit her caffeine consumption. However, caffeine consumption itself does not cause urinary incontinence.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has urge incontinence, as evidenced by her sudden urge to urinate resulting in frequent small volume voids. This condition can also cause nocturia, and be exacerbated by bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine).

She delivered three children vaginally, all more than 30 years ago. Her current medications are aspirin and atenolol. Vital signs and pelvic examination are normal. Urinalysis is unremarkable. She has tried bladder training with timed voiding, pelvic floor therapy, and avoidance of bladder irritants without improvement. Which one of the following management steps is most appropriate for this patient?

A) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic studies and an evaluation of the postvoid residual are not typically indicated in the evaluation of patients with urge incontinence unless more complicated forms of incontinence, such as overflow incontinence, are suspected. B) INCORRECT:

A vaginal pessary is used for stress incontinence, not urge incontinence.

C) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing atenolol (a beta-blocker) would be appropriate if the patient’s symptoms were temporally tied to initiation of that medication. Many medications, including both beta-blockers and calcium-channel blockers (e.g., amlodipine), can contribute to the development of incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

A urine culture is not indicated in a patient who has a normal urinalysis.

E) CORRECT:

Urinary incontinence, which is common in women ≥ 65 years of age, usually manifests as urge or stress incontinence. Urge incontinence is defined as the involuntary leakage of urine, associated with a sudden, compelling desire to void. Leakage of urine before reaching the toilet, a typical symptom of urge incontinence, occurs when the bladder contracts with little warning and overcomes the sphincter mechanism. Other signs associated with overactive bladder and urge incontinence include nocturia and daytime frequency. Individuals with stress incontinence leak urine when there is a sudden increase in abdominal pressure and malfunction of the urethral sphincter.

Initial management for urge incontinence typically involves bladder training (patient education and “timed voiding”), pelvic muscle exercises, modification of fluid intake, and avoidance of irritants. However, anticholinergic antimuscarinic agents are the mainstay of therapy and are more effective than bladder training alone. Oxybutynin is a reasonable first-line choice that can be given in a once-daily formulation.

Key learning point: The most appropriate pharmacologic therapy for a postmenopausal woman with urge incontinence is an anticholinergic agent.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of urinary leakage over the past year. She reports involuntarily losing small amounts of urine after experiencing a sudden need to void. She has difficulty making it to the bathroom in time, and only feels comfortable going out into public if she has documented the location of all nearby restrooms. She also has begun to wake up at night to urinate. These symptoms have persisted despite 6 months of bladder training and weight loss, and reducing soda and coffee intake. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most likely to be effective in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Antimuscarinic agents such as oxybutynin antagonize parasympathetic muscarinic M3 receptors found in the bladder. Muscarinic M3 receptor stimulation is responsible for bladder contraction; thus, inhibition leads to improvement of symptoms in patients with urge incontinence. Pharmacotherapy should be reserved as an additional therapeutic option for patients in which behavioral therapy and lifestyle modifications alone were insufficient. Because muscarinic M3 receptors are located in various glands and in smooth muscles, anticholinergic agents have several systemic side effects, including pupillary dilation, dry mouth, constipation, tachycardia, and impaired cognition. They should be used with caution in patients predisposed to delirium (e.g., elderly patients). Beta-3 agonists, such as mirabegron, can be used to treat urge incontinence in patients who do not tolerate or have contraindications to antimuscarinic therapy.

See “Overview of sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system receptors” table.
Image Description:

Depicted here are the subtypes of adrenergic receptors (α and β) and cholinergic receptors (M: muscarinic, N: nicotinic), which trigger the organ response described when activated. The sympathetic chain is represented by the yellow chain of ganglia to the left of the spinal cord. Also depicted are cranial nerves (CN III, VII, IX, X) emerging from the brainstem.

B) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1 antagonists such as tamsulosin are commonly prescribed to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia, a condition that may cause overflow incontinence secondary to urinary retention in men. Antagonism of this receptor causes relaxation of the bladder neck muscles. In patients with urge incontinence due to detrusor overactivity, relaxation of the bladder neck muscles would likely worsen symptoms as there would be no resistance to counteract bladder contraction.

C) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of beta-3 adrenergic receptors found on smooth muscle cells of the urinary bladder promotes detrusor muscle relaxation, thereby delaying the need for micturition. Antagonism of these receptors would cause increased detrusor contraction and would worsen symptoms in patients with urge incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

While beta-2 agonism would cause detrusor muscle relaxation of the bladder, it is not commonly used to treat urge incontinence. Beta-2 adrenergic agonists (e.g., albuterol or salmeterol) are used to manage asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, as they are very potent bronchodilators.

E) INCORRECT:

Agonism of muscarinic M3 receptors causes bladder contraction. Drugs such as bethanechol stimulate expulsion of urine and are commonly used for patients with overflow urinary incontinence. Unlike urge incontinence, overflow incontinence usually causes continuous dribbling and is not typically associated with a sudden urge to void.

F) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic receptor antagonists such as rocuronium are primarily used as muscle relaxants intraoperatively. Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are found in presynaptic neurons of the autonomic ganglia, and postsynaptic neurons of the neuromuscular junction of skeletal muscles. Bladder contraction is regulated by smooth muscle, not skeletal muscle; so drugs affecting the nicotinic receptor pathway would not be effective at improving symptoms of urge incontinence.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has urge incontinence, as evidenced by her sudden urge to urinate resulting in frequent involuntary loss of small amounts of urine and nocturia. Because she has failed conservative treatment, she qualifies for pharmacologic treatment. Oxybutynin would be an appropriate first-line medication.
